content: The "No Discrimination in Health Insurance Act of 2008" aims to eliminate pre-existing condition exclusions in all group and individual health insurance policies. It also requires health insurance issuers to openly disclose premium prices for policies within specific geographic areas to ensure uniformity. The "No Discrimination in Health Insurance Act of 2008" eliminates preexisting condition exclusions in group health plans and insurance coverage. It prohibits preexisting condition exclusions and affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. The "No Discrimination in Health Insurance Act of 2008" eliminates preexisting condition exclusions in group health plans and insurance coverage. It prohibits affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. The "No Discrimination in Health Insurance Act of 2008" eliminates preexisting condition exclusions in group health plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It prohibits imposing any pre-existing condition exclusion and removes certain subsections while redesignating others. The item in the table of sections of chapter 100 of the Internal Revenue Code relating to section 9801 is amended. Section 9801 of the Public Health Service Act prohibits preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and insurance coverage. The Public Health Service Act prohibits preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and insurance coverage. Amendments include defining an affiliation period as a waiting period before health insurance coverage starts and guaranteeing availability of group health insurance coverage to employers of all sizes in the group market. Subsections (c), (d), (e), and (g) are removed, and special enrollment periods are redesignated. Section 2711 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to remove references to "small" employers and adjust language regarding health insurance coverage. Section 2711 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to remove references to "small" employers and adjust language regarding health insurance coverage. Health insurance issuers must charge the same premium price for the same coverage and disclose the premium price openly. The amendment to Section 2711 of the Public Health Service Act removes references to "small" employers and adjusts language regarding health insurance coverage. It requires health insurance issuers to charge the same premium price for the same coverage uniformly across different family categories and geographic areas. The amendment allows variations in premiums over different policy years. The amendment to Section 2721 of the Public Health Service Act applies nondiscrimination rules to nonfederal governmental plans, effective for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2009. Special rules apply for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section do not apply to plan years before the later of the termination of collective bargaining agreements or January 1, 2010. Plan amendments made to comply with these requirements do not constitute a termination of the collective bargaining agreement. SEC. 3. NONDISCRIMINATION IN INDIVIDUAL HEALTH INSURANCE. Section 2741 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to guarantee issue of individual health insurance coverage and uniform premiums. Health insurance issuers must offer coverage to eligible individuals without denial or enrollment refusal. The amendment to Section 2741 guarantees issue of individual health insurance coverage without denial or enrollment refusal. Health insurance issuers must charge the same premium for the same coverage in both individual and group markets, and openly disclose pricing information as specified by the Secretary. The amendment ensures guaranteed issue of individual health insurance coverage with uniform pricing disclosure requirements set by the Secretary. The pricing must be consistent for family coverage and across different geographic areas. The amendment allows variations in premiums based on a uniform monthly premium over different policy years. Eligible individuals are defined as citizens, lawful permanent residents, or aliens lawfully residing in the United States. Subsection (c) is removed, and subsections (d) and (e) are redesignated as (c) and (d) respectively. The amendment includes rules to deter individuals from enrolling in health insurance only after developing an illness and from disenrolling during periods of low risk. The Secretary may establish uniform rules to address adverse selection in individual health insurance coverage. The amendment allows for rules to consider individuals' financial circumstances for enrolling or disenrolling in health insurance. It also includes a conforming amendment and specifies that the changes apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market after December 31, 2008.
